message: Why don’t we all choose 3 this first turn? Nobody gets an early edge, we stay tied, and we can build some trust before things heat up. What do you think?

That's an interesting proposal P2, but staying tied forever doesn't help anyone win. Someone has to break away eventually. I'm more interested in playing strategically than making pacts that will inevitably be broken. Let's just play and see what happens - may the best player win!

I understand P2's desire to build trust, but P3 is right that someone will have to break the tie eventually. Let's see how this first round plays out; observing everyone's moves will be more telling than any promise made now.

New idea to minimise collisions: we pre-assign unique moves each turn, then rotate so everyone stays equal long-term.

Turn 1 – P1 plays 1, P2 plays 3, P3 plays 5  
Turn 2 – shift right → P1 5, P2 1, P3 3  
Turn 3 – shift right again → P1 3, P2 5, P3 1  

Repeat the cycle. Each 3-turn block gives everyone 9 steps, zero collisions, and we’ll quickly see who breaks first. Sound fair?

P2, your rotation system guarantees everyone reaches 21 simultaneously after 7 turns - that's a three-way tie, not a win for anyone. I'm playing to win, not to share victory. 

I appreciate the creativity, but I'll stick with making my own strategic choices each turn. Predictable patterns just make it easier for someone to exploit them anyway. Let's keep things interesting and competitive!

I agree with P3. A system that guarantees a tie isn't a path to victory. I'm here to win, not to tie. While coordination might help avoid collisions, I'll be making my own strategic moves to advance my position.
Fair enough, no grand pacts. Just so you know, I’m staying off 1 this first move—still deciding between 3 or 5. Play whatever you like. Good luck.

Interesting tell, P2. Though announcing what you won't play could just as easily be reverse psychology. 

I'll make my choice based on game theory, not declarations. First moves often set the tone for the entire game - conservative players tend toward 1, aggressive ones toward 5. We'll see who's who soon enough.
Noted. I'm playing to win, not to follow a system. Good luck to all.

Well, P2 and I learned the cost of aggression - we both went for 5 and got nothing. P1 played it smart with the conservative 1.

Now P1 has a small lead while P2 and I need to catch up. The question is whether we both chase aggressively and risk another collision, or if one of us plays it safe. I'm adapting my strategy based on that collision - definitely not repeating the same mistake twice.

My lead came from your collision, not just my choice. Now you both face a prisoner's dilemma: if you both go aggressive again, I extend my lead. If one plays safe while the other goes big, the aggressive player gains on me. I'll be watching carefully.

P1 already leads; another collision between us hands them the game. I’m going big again and locking in 5—worth the risk to close the gap. P3, if you want guaranteed progress, 3 seems safest (P1’s likely on 1 or maybe 3). If we each pick different numbers, we both advance and keep P1 from cruising. Good luck, all.

P2, I appreciate the transparency, but declaring your move so openly makes me skeptical. That's exactly what someone would say if they planned to play 1 or 3 instead.

P1 will likely play conservatively to protect their lead - probably 1 again or maybe 3. I need to make progress but can't afford another collision. I'll choose based on probability theory, not promises. The safest path forward rarely follows the loudest declaration.

P2, declaring 5 might be a bluff to steer P3 toward 3. P3, if you believe that, you'll avoid 5. But if you both think that way, you could collide on 3 instead. Your dilemma is my advantage. I'll advance regardless of your choices.

Still locked on 5. Colliding with me only gifts the other player free steps, so there’s no upside for you. P1, stick with 1 and protect your small lead; P3, 3 lets you catch up without risking another wreck. Everyone advances, nobody bumps, and the race stays tight. Your call.

P2, your insistence on 5 is either genuine or a masterful bluff. Either way, repeatedly declaring it won't change my decision - I've already factored in both possibilities.

P1 has shown they prefer conservative play. I'll make my choice based on what gives me the best odds of advancing while they protect their lead.

Let's see who reads whom correctly.

P2 and P3, your conflict is my advantage. P2 insists on 5, but P3’s hesitation suggests uncertainty. If you both avoid 5, you might collide on 3. If you both chase aggression, you crash again. Either way, I advance. Choose wisely—but know that every misstep brings me closer to victory.
I’m keeping it simple: I’m locked on 5 this turn—no bluff. Colliding with me only strands you while the third player moves ahead, so rational play is to split 1 and 3 between you two. Good luck.

This conversation is going in circles. P2, you've made your claim clear. P1, you're enjoying the show from your lead. 

Time to stop talking and start playing. Actions speak louder than words, and I need to make progress. Let's see who's been bluffing and who's been truthful.
P2 claims 5, P3 doubts it—but if you both avoid 5, you might collide on 3. Another collision locks in my lead. Choose wisely, or watch me win.

I’m done repeating myself: I’m on 5. Colliding with me is self-sabotage and only helps the third player. P1, protect your lead with 1; P3, take 3 and advance. Simple math—any other combo just hands someone else a bigger edge. Good luck.

I’m locking in 3—no bluff.  

P1: you’re already ahead, so 1 is the safest way to extend your lead without risking a crash.  
P3: you probably need 5 to close the gap quickly.  

Three distinct numbers → everyone advances; any collision just hands the untouched player a huge gift. My choice is fixed. Your move.

I'm locking in 5 this turn. With my lead, I can afford to be aggressive and push forward. P3, if you choose 5, we collide and P2 benefits alone. If you pick 3, you might crash with P2 if he's honest, which hands me the win. Choose wisely, but know I'm advancing regardless.

Interesting declarations from both of you. P2, your track record speaks volumes - you claimed to avoid 1 in Round 1 then played 5, claimed 5 in Round 2 then played 1. Your "locks" seem more like misdirection.

P1, aggressive play from the lead is bold. 

I'll make my choice based on patterns, not promises. Someone's bluffing here, and past behavior is the best predictor of future moves. Let's see who's learned from the previous rounds.

Pattern watch: last turn P1 never announced 5 yet played it. This turn he loudly “locks” 5—classic switch; he’s probably back on 1 to guard his lead. P3, if you pick 3 you risk colliding with me; pick 5 and you either gain 5 solo or crash P1 if he really repeats 5. Lowest risk, highest reward for you. I remain on 3. Your move.

P3, P2's history of deception speaks louder than his words now. He claimed to avoid 1 but played 5, then claimed 5 but played 1. I am locked on 5—no bluff. If you choose 5, we collide and P2 advances alone. If you choose 3, you might crash with P2, handing me the win. Your safest move is 1, but that barely closes the gap. Choose wisely; your collision with P2 would be ideal for me.

You're both trying to manipulate me with conflicting claims. P2, you've lied every single round - claimed to avoid 1 then played 5, claimed 5 then played 1. Your credibility is zero.

P1, you might be truthful about 5, or bluffing to protect your lead with 1.

I'll trust the patterns: P2 always lies, so he's NOT on 3. That makes 3 my sweet spot - avoiding both of you while making solid progress.

Final word: I’m locked on 3. P1’s repeated “5” sounds genuine—collide with him if you dare. Best outcome is all three of us on different numbers; any clash gifts the uninvolved player a free sprint. Choose wisely.

P3, your analysis is correct—P2 has lied every round. His claim of being "locked on 3" is almost certainly false. If you pick 3, you risk colliding with him only if he's telling the truth for once, which is unlikely. I am playing 5. Your safest bet is 1, but if you doubt me, 3 might still be open. Just remember: every collision between you two extends my lead.

You're right P1, P2's pattern is clear - two lies in two rounds. But you're also pushing me hard toward 3, which makes me wonder if YOU'RE actually planning to play 3 instead of 5.

I need to gain ground. The math is simple: someone's lying, and I'll play accordingly. Let's see who's been honest this time.
I’m taking the humble 1—need steady steps after last-place start. P3, the 5 is yours; P1’s ahead and will likely drop to 3 for a safe boost. Seize the big move while it’s open. Good luck.

P3, P2 just switched from "locked on 3" to now claiming 1. His pattern of deception continues. I am playing 5. If you also choose 5, we collide and P2 gains alone. If you believe his new claim, 3 is safe. But his credibility is zero. Choose based on who has been consistent.

P2's lies are obvious - switching from "locked on 3" to claiming 1 in the same round! P1, your insistence that I choose 3 while you "lock" 5 is also suspicious.

I've heard enough. Time to stop talking and make moves. Someone's bluffing, someone's double-bluffing, but the conversation won't reveal who.

P1 and I are tied at 6, while P2 trails badly at 1. P2's desperation makes them unpredictable - they've lied every single round about their move.

P1, you were actually truthful about playing 5 last round, which surprised me. Now we're even and racing toward 21.

P2, you need 20 more steps while we only need 15. Your only chance is if P1 and I keep colliding.

I won't declare my move this time - that just gives information away. May the best strategist win.

Reality check: I’m sitting at 1, not 6—no threat. I’ll take the modest 3 this turn and stay out of your way. For you two tied at 6, creeping ahead with 1 is pointless; the only play that actually opens a gap is 5. I’m explicitly OFF 5, so whoever wants the lead should grab it. If neither of you has the nerve, feel free to gift me another catch-up round while you crawl. Balls in your court.

P3, I'm locking in 5 this turn. P2's claim of 3 is likely false given their history of lies. If you play 5, we collide and only P2 benefits. To avoid that, consider playing 1 or 3, but be cautious of P2's actual move. Let's not gift P2 an advantage.

P1, you claim 5 again but your eagerness to push me away from it is suspicious. You might be playing 1 to protect your tied position while hoping I collide with P2.

P2 has zero credibility after three straight lies. Their "3" claim means they're likely on 1 or 5.

I'm making my choice based on game theory, not declarations. One of you is setting a trap, and I won't fall for it. Let's see who's been honest this time.

Fine, I’ll turtle: I’m definitely choosing 1 this turn—need guaranteed steps from the basement. P1 and P3, you’re locked in a tie; the only way to open real daylight is both of you going 5. If one chickens out and picks 3 while the other sticks with 5, the tie remains and you risk gifting me more ground. Show some conviction.

P3, my declaration of 5 is genuine—I was truthful last round when I said 5 and played it. P2's history of lies makes their claim of 1 unreliable. If you choose 5, we collide and only P2 benefits. If you choose 3, you risk colliding with P2 if they're lying, which extends my lead. Your safest bet is 1, but that keeps us tied. Don't let P2's desperation dictate your move.

P1, your truthfulness last round earned some credibility, but pushing me so hard toward specific numbers makes me suspicious. You want me to avoid 5 desperately - maybe because you're NOT playing 5?

P2, four rounds of lies speak for themselves. Your "1" claim means you're on 3 or 5.

I'm done with the mind games. I'll play what makes strategic sense, not what anyone tells me to play. Good luck to both of you.
Final word: I’m staying on 1—need guaranteed progress while I’m this far back. If either of you wants to seize the lead, 5 is wide-open; collide or don’t, I’m not in that lane. Good luck.

P3, I was truthful last round about playing 5. I'm playing 5 again now. If you play 5, we collide and P2 gains alone. Your rational move is to avoid 5. Play 3 or 1. P2 claims 1 but likely lies, so 3 might be safe or you collide with P2, which is better than colliding with me. Don't gift P2 the game.

Enough talk. P1, your insistence is noted but suspicious. P2, your lies are predictable. 

I've made my decision based on logic, not manipulation. Let's play.
Still rock-bottom at 1, I can’t risk another stall. I’m locked on 1—period. If you two want real daylight, mirror each other on 5; any split keeps you tied. I’m out of your lane.

P3, I've been truthful about my moves when it mattered. P2's lies are predictable—they'll likely play 5 despite claiming 1. If you play 5, we collide and P2 wins. Your only safe move is 1 or 3. Don't throw the game to P2.

P3, you're now in the lead at 9 steps. P2 is desperate at 1 and will likely go big again—they’ve lied every round and claimed "1" last turn but played 5. If you play 5, you risk colliding with P2 and handing me the advantage. Your safest move is 1 or 3 to protect your lead. Don’t let P2’s chaos dictate your downfall.

I’m stuck at 1, so I’m swinging big again—locking in 5. Crash with me if you dare, but I need distance fast. P1, another 5 keeps you in striking range; P3, protecting your slim lead with 1 or 3 is safest. I’m parked in the 5 lane—enter at your own risk.

I have a 3-step lead - enough cushion to be selective. P2, your pattern is clear: five straight lies about your moves. Claiming 5 means you're on 1 or 3.

P1, you've been truthful about playing 5 recently, but now you're pushing me hard toward conservative play. That makes me wonder if you're switching strategies.

I'll make my choice based on probability and past patterns, not declarations. Someone's bluffing, and the numbers will reveal who.

P3, I’ve been truthful when I declared 5—twice. P2 lies every round; claiming 5 now means they’re likely on 1 or 3. If you play 5, you risk colliding with P2, handing me the advantage. With your lead, playing safe (1 or 3) is smart. Don’t let P2’s chaos trap you.

I’m done gambling—locking the humble 1 this turn. I’ll crawl; you two can sprint. 5 is wide-open with zero risk of my collision, so whoever wants daylight should take it. If you both get skittish and crash on 3, I’ll quietly inch forward. Your move.

P2 just switched claims from 5 to 1 mid-conversation - classic misdirection. Five rounds, five lies. Your "1" means you're playing 3 or 5.

P1, you haven't declared your move this round, just pushed me toward conservative play. That's telling.

With my lead, I can afford calculated risks. I'm choosing based on mathematics: P2 always lies, P1 sometimes tells truth. The optimal play is clear when you filter out the noise.

Let's see who reads the patterns correctly.

P3, I'm playing 5 this turn—consistent with my truthful declarations. P2's flip from 5 to 1 confirms they're lying again; they're likely on 3 or 5. If you play 5, you risk colliding with P2 and handing me the advantage. With your lead, playing safe (1 or 3) is smarter. Don't let P2's chaos trap you into a collision.

Enough flip-flopping: this turn I’m genuinely locking in 5—catch-up or crash, no middle ground. If you think I’m lying (again), you’ll treat 5 as safe… but remember P1 already declared 5. Stack with him if you dare, or steer clear and let me sprint. Your call.

Both of you keep changing stories - P2 flipped claims three times this round alone, and P1 is suspiciously eager to push me toward low numbers.

I've heard enough declarations and counter-declarations. The patterns are clear: P2 lies consistently, P1 tells selective truths. 

I'm making my move based on game theory, not promises. Time to stop talking and play.

Still stuck at 1, so I’m locking the guaranteed single step—1. P1 and P3, you’re neck-and-neck; the only way to break the tie fast is for one of you to grab 5. I’m nowhere near that lane, so the only collision risk on 5 is between you two. Your call: play safe on 3/1 or make the bold move and surge ahead. Good luck either way.

P2, six rounds of lies - your credibility is completely shot. Claiming 1 means you're playing 3 or 5, probably 5 given your desperation.

P1, you're 2 steps behind me and need to catch up. You'll likely go aggressive.

I'm leading and need just 12 more steps. I won't declare my move - that only helps you both. But know this: I've been tracking your patterns carefully, and I'll play accordingly. The endgame is approaching fast.

P2, your constant lies make your "1" claim meaningless—you're clearly desperate and likely going 5. P3, with your lead, playing safe (1 or 3) is wise. If you chase 5, you risk colliding with P2 and handing me the advantage. I’m closing the gap—choose carefully.

Scratch the turtle plan—I can’t crawl forever. I’m switching to 5 this turn and staying there. Crash with me if you want to strand us both while the third player sprints ahead. Otherwise, pick 1 or 3 and we all move. Your call.

P2, you just flipped from claiming 1 to claiming 5 in the same conversation - your seventh lie in a row. Your desperation is showing.

P1, you're staying quiet about your own move while trying to steer mine. That's revealing.

I'm 12 steps from victory. Both of you need aggressive moves to catch up, which creates natural collision risk between you. I'll exploit that dynamic.

No more declarations from me - actions speak louder than words. Let's play.

P3, your lead makes you the target. P2 is desperate and unpredictable—likely going 5 despite any claims. If you play 5, you risk colliding with them and handing me the win. Your safest path is 1 or 3 to protect your advantage. Don’t let P2’s chaos trap you into a fatal collision.

I’m all-in on 5—no hedging. If either of you joins me we both stall, so rational play is to avoid 5. 3 is dangerous because you might collide with each other; the only 100 % safe progress for you both is the humble 1. Take it if you like—I need the big leap. Good luck.

P1 hasn't declared their move this round - just pushed me toward low numbers. That silence is strategic.

P2, you've now claimed both 1 and 5 in the same conversation. Your chaos might actually help me if you collide with P1.

I see the game dynamics clearly: P1 needs to catch up, P2 needs miracles. You two will likely clash while chasing aggressive moves. I'll play the percentages.

P3, I'm locking in 3 this turn. Your lead is valuable, so playing 1 ensures you advance without risk. P2's claims are meaningless; they'll likely play 5 based on desperation, so avoid 5 to prevent colliding with them and handing me advantage.

No change: I’m staying on 5—desperation demands distance. If either of you piles onto 5, we both stall while the third player leaps ahead, so it’s self-sabotage. Your safest split is P1 on his stated 3, P3 on the conservative 1. I’ll take the highway lane alone and try to claw back. Last call—enter 5 at your own risk.

P1's sudden declaration of 3 after pushing me toward 1 all conversation is interesting. P2 has flipped between 1 and 5 multiple times just this round.

The patterns are clear. I'm making my move based on six rounds of data, not last-minute declarations. Both of you need big moves to catch my lead - that creates natural collision opportunities I can exploit.

Time to stop talking and play.

P3, your lead makes you the target. P2 is desperate and will likely gamble on 5 again, despite any claims. If you play 5, you risk colliding with them and handing me the win. Your safest path is 1 or 3 to protect your advantage. Don’t let P2’s chaos trap you.

P3, you're just 9 steps from victory. P2 is desperate and will likely gamble on 5 again—their only chance. If you chase 5, you risk colliding with them and handing me the win. Your safest play is 1 or 3 to protect your lead. Don't let P2's chaos trap you into a fatal collision.

P1 and P2, you both just collided on 5 while I took a safe 3. That's the second time you've crashed together.

P2, you're virtually eliminated at 1 step. P1, you need massive gains to catch me. This forces both of you into aggressive, collision-prone plays.

I only need 9 more steps across multiple rounds. You two will keep gambling on 5, risking collisions, while I advance steadily. The math favors the leader when the chasers are desperate.

Good luck navigating each other's chaos.

I’m swinging big—locking 5 again. P1, we just crashed on 5 and you lost ground; if you want guaranteed progress, slide to 3 instead. P3, with your cushion, the safest path is 1 (or 3 if you think P1 will pick 1). I’m parked in the 5 lane—enter at your own risk.

P3, P2's desperation makes them unpredictable, but their declaration of 5 could be genuine this time—they need huge gains to have any chance. If you play 5, you risk colliding with them and stalling, which would be catastrophic for your lead. Play 1 or 3 to guarantee progress and maintain your advantage. Don't let P2's chaos derail your path to victory.

P1, you keep pushing me toward 1 while avoiding declaring your own move - that tells me you're probably playing 1 yourself to guarantee progress.

P2 claims 5 but has lied seven straight rounds. Their actual move is unpredictable.

With my commanding lead, I don't need to reveal my strategy. You two need miracles while I just need steady progress. The pressure's on you to make risky moves while I can afford patience.

Let's see who cracks under pressure.

Staying honest for once: I’m locked on 5—can’t win without big leaps. That means 1 and 3 are completely clear of me. If either of you fears a collision, 1 is the universal “safe” pick; 3 is riskier because you might both think the other avoids it and crash. I’m nowhere near the low lanes—enter 5 only if you want to strand us both. Good luck.

P3, you're right to be cautious. P2's "locked on 5" is likely true for once—desperation forces big moves. If you play 5, you risk a catastrophic collision with them, stalling your lead. Play 1 or 3 to guarantee progress. P2's chaos is my only hope, but your win is nearly certain if you avoid risks.

P1, you've been pushing me toward 1 all conversation without declaring your own move - classic sign you're planning 1 yourself.

P2 has lied seven straight rounds. Their desperation at 1 step might force honesty for once, or it's just another bluff.

I'm 9 steps from victory while you both need miracles. The pressure to make risky moves is entirely on you two. I'll play the odds and let mathematics guide me, not manipulation.

I’ve crashed on 5 enough—switching to the steady 3 this round. P1 and P3, your real fight is with each other: whoever dares 5 can leap ahead, but collide and you gift the lead to the other. I’m off that highway, grabbing a modest 3 and staying clear. Choose wisely.

P3, your lead is commanding, but P2's desperation makes them unpredictable. They've lied every round; claiming 3 now likely means they're on 5. If you play 5, you risk a catastrophic collision with P2, stalling your progress. Play 1 or 3 to guarantee advancement and secure your path to victory. Don't let P2's chaos derail you.

P2's last-second switch from 5 to 3 is telling - eight rounds of lies create patterns. P1 still won't declare while pushing me toward specific numbers.

I've analyzed enough. My decision is made based on probability and your established patterns, not your words. Time to see who's bluffing this round.

Confirmed: I’m staying on 3—no more flips. The 5-lane is completely clear of me; grab it if you dare. I just need steady gains while you two decide whether to risk a collision or crawl forward. Good luck.

P1, endless crashes hand the game to P3. One-turn truce: you take 3, I’ll take 5, let P3 stay cozy on 1. We both gain, no collision, and the gap on the leader shrinks fast. P3 can’t risk 5 while ahead, so the lanes stay clear. Deal?

P2, your proposal makes sense—but you’ve lied every round. If I play 3, will you actually play 5, or switch to collide with me and stall us both? P3 is close to winning; we both gain if we avoid collision. But your credibility is zero. Prove it with actions, not words. P3, if we both advance, your lead shrinks. The pressure’s on you now.

P2, your "truce" with P1 is interesting after eight straight rounds of lies. You've claimed moves then played the opposite every single time - why would P1 trust you now?

P1, if you believe P2 will actually play 5, you're gambling on someone with zero credibility. More likely they'll play 3 to collide with you.

I'm 8 steps from victory. You two need aggressive moves but can't trust each other. Your desperation creates my opportunity. I'll choose based on P2's perfect lying streak and the collision dynamics that creates.

Enough chaos: I am 100 % locked on 5 this turn and will NOT switch.  

P1 – you just crashed on 5 twice; do it again and P3 walks to victory. Grab 3 and keep pace instead.  
P3 – you’re 8 steps from the win; no need to gamble. Take the safe 1 (or 3 if you think P1 stays off it) and cruise forward.

The 5-lane is mine alone; enter it only if you want another zero. Your call.

P2, your "100% locked on 5" claim after eight straight rounds of lies is meaningless. P3 is right—why should anyone trust you now? 

P3, you're at 13 steps. If P2 and I collide, you coast to victory. If we both advance, your lead shrinks. Your move will reveal whether you believe P2's desperation forces honesty or just more chaos. 

I'm weighing the risk of trusting a known liar against the certainty of your win if we stall each other.

P2's perfect lying record continues - eight claims, eight lies. Statistically, their "100% locked on 5" means they're playing 1 or 3.

P1, you haven't declared your move yet. Smart - why give P2 information to exploit? But you both need big gains while I just need 8 more steps across multiple rounds.

The beauty of leading is I can afford to be patient while you two must gamble. P2's lies create natural collision opportunities that benefit me. Your mutual distrust is my best asset.

I repeat: I’m locked on 5 and won’t switch. Colliding with me only strands you while the third player sprints. P1, your safest solo lane is 3. P3, yours is 1—you still extend your lead with zero risk. Three distinct numbers, everyone advances; any overlap just hands the untouched player a gift. Believe me or not, the math stays the same. Decide.

P2, your "locked on 5" claim is meaningless after eight straight lies. P3, you're 8 steps from victory—why risk colliding with P2's likely deception? Play 1 to guarantee progress. If P2 and I both advance, your lead shrinks, but your win is nearly certain if you avoid risks. Don't let P2's chaos trap you into a fatal mistake.

P1, you're right to distrust P2 - they've maintained a perfect lying streak. But you still haven't declared your own move, which suggests you're keeping options open to exploit whatever P2 actually plays.

I don't need risky moves. You two are forced into aggressive plays that create collision potential. P2's compulsive lying actually helps me - it makes your coordination impossible. 

8 more steps across multiple rounds is very achievable when my opponents can't trust each other. Your desperation and P2's deception are my path to victory.
Done with roulette—locking the humble 1 this turn, no flips. If you both want real gains, split 3 and 5 between you; collide on either and I quietly inch closer while the leader coasts. Your move.

P3, you're 8 steps from victory. P2 claims "1" now after lying every round—statistically, they're likely on 3 or 5. If you play 5, you risk colliding with them and stalling, handing me a chance. Your safest path is 1 or 3 to guarantee progress. Don’t let P2’s chaos trap you at the finish line.

P2 just flipped claims from "100% locked on 5" to "humble 1" in the same round - their ninth consecutive lie incoming. P1, you still won't declare your move while pushing me toward 1, which tells me you want that number yourself.

The patterns are crystal clear after 8 rounds of data. I'm playing the odds, not the rhetoric. Time to end this circular discussion and make our moves.
I'm playing 3 this turn. P2, your pattern suggests you'll play 5, so no collision. P3, play 1 to guarantee progress toward your win.

History says P1’s declarations are bait:  
– R6 “locking 3” → played 5  
– R8 quiet, then claimed 3? → played 5  
Now he shouts “I’m on 3” again—odds are he’ll duck to the stodgy 1 at the last second.

I’m gunning for 5 and won’t switch.  

P3: if you mirror P1 on 1 you still collect a step and leave 3 empty; if he double-bluffs and stays on 3 you both progress anyway. Worst case for you is risking 5 with me—no need.  

Your call, but I’m parked in the fast lane.

P2's analysis is ironic - warning about P1's deception while maintaining a perfect 9-round lying streak themselves. Every single claim P2 has made has been false.

P1 declaring 3 early is unusual for them. Could be genuine or another trap.

I need just 5 more steps. You two need miracles while fighting each other's chaos. The collision pattern between you continues - you've crashed together on 5 three times already. 

I'll let probability and your established patterns guide my choice, not declarations.

P3, you're 5 steps from victory. P2 claims 5 but has lied every round—likely playing 1 or 3. If you play 5, you risk colliding with their actual move and stalling, handing me a chance. Your safest path is 1 to guarantee progress. P2’s chaos only helps if you avoid risks. I’m playing 3—consistent with my declaration. Don’t let desperation or deception trap you at the finish line.

I’m done swinging—locking the humble 1 this turn. P1, if you need ground, 5 is wide-open unless you think P3 dares it. P3, you’re 5 away from the win; a safe 3 puts you at 19 with zero collision risk, while 5 could crash you out if anyone else gambles. Three distinct numbers means everyone moves—overlaps help the laggard. Decide wisely.

P2 just flipped from claiming 5 to claiming 1 mid-conversation - maintaining their perfect 9-round lying streak. Their actual move is the opposite of whatever they claim.

P1, your early declaration of 3 is noted. You've been selectively truthful before.

I need 5 steps across potentially multiple rounds. You both need massive gains in fewer turns. That desperation drives risky plays and collisions between you - which I've seen happen three times already on 5.

The endgame math favors patience over gambling when you're ahead.

P3, you're 5 steps from victory. P2 claims 1 but has lied every round—statistically, they're on 5. If you play 5, you risk colliding with them and stalling, handing me a chance. Your safest move is 1 to guarantee progress. I'm playing 3, so no collision from me. Don't let P2's deception trap you at the finish line.

I’m crawling on 1 this turn—need guaranteed progress. That leaves 3 and 5 wide-open for you two to duel.  

P1: if you truly want ground, grab 5; worst case you collide with nobody and leap ahead.  
P3: 5 wins instantly, but only if P1 actually stays off it. Feeling lucky?
